bibl.title: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Frederick F. Russell, September 16, 1928

div1.p: Carter suggests that Brown's salary be continued through October even though Brown has offered to work for free. She also thanks Russell for facilitating repayments of advances that she and Henry Rose Carter made towards Theodore Hayne's medical education as the work and her health have affected her finances adversely.

div1.head: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Frederick F. Russell, September 16, 1928

opener.dateline:
The Westmoreland,
2122 California St., N. W.
Washington, D. C.
September 156, 1928

div1.p:
This is just to say that the work on the bibliography of
the History of Yellow Fever is being so pressed at present, in expec-
tation of Dr. Frost calling for the verified references, that I do not
feel that you would wish me to take time therefrom to go into the de-
tails of what has been accomplished since my last letter to you. I
shall only state that Miss Brown and I have done much successful work
and have put in all the time we possibly could, including night work
and Sundays. I am, however, being very careful to avoid another break-
down, as I certainly must “last” this time until the book is finished.

In connection with Miss Brown's work: she told me yesterday
that she does not expect a salary after this month, although she in-
tends to continue to work with me until the bibliography is ready to
go to press, and “ to work just as hard as heretofore.” It would seem to
me, however, provided you see it as I do, that it would be no more than
fair that her salary continue until the end of October instead of stop-
ping, as she suggests, at the end of September. Miss Brown will be
working for us all of the month of October (and later) and she is now so well up
on what needs to be done that, even when I run over to Baltimore to
work with Dr. Frost, she can “carry on” most satisfactorily by herself.
Indeed, much of our night work is now done apart, only, of course, I go
over and verify her findings with her later.before we mark the refs. as completed. Miss Brown has done, and
is doing, beautiful work and, of course, has given us far more of her
time than either she or I anticipated when we started in together.
Had she not done so, the bibliography would be far less near completion,
as there was a tremendous mass of literature to be gone over, in six lan-
-2-
lan-
guages, and only her exceptional equipment for the task, combined with
hard work: enthusiasm and long hours on both our parts could have brought
the work to its present state in the comparatively short time we have
been working together. When one considers in addition what a horror the
past summer has been I cannot adequately express my appreciation of what
all that Miss Brown has done.

By the way, and a propos of deep appreciation, I had intended
sooner to mention having heard from Theodore Hayne, just prior to his
sailing for West Africa, telling me of the arrangements he had made with
you for the repayments, from his monthly salary, of the money advanced
him by Father and myself for his medical education. I hope that Theodore
is not making these monthly payments larger than is convenient to him, for
it would have been a privelege to help such a man get a start under any
conditions. I must admit, however, that the money is a God-send at pres-
ent, as not only have I long been under heavy expense, on account of
sickness and other emergencies, but also it naturally costs far more to
live when one is below par physically and has to save oneself entirely for
one's work. However, in using Theodore's money, although I am going into
my capital thereby, at least I am not going invested capital, as I had to
do when I was sick. It is almost a miracle then to have these repayments
start at this particular time and I am most grateful, not only to Theodore
for being so generous in the amount of his salary assigned for this pur-
pose, but to yourself for making the present system of repayment possible.

I congratulate both the I. H. D. and Theodore Hayne on the
present connection. Father and I thought the world of him, indeed Father
considered him the finest and the ablest of the young men with whom he
was associated in the latter years of his field work.

I hope that you can let me know a day or so in advance when you
contemplate coming to Washington, as I generally start to the Library be-
be-
-3-
fore the morning's mail is delivered: long training with Father having
accustomed me to early rising and to starting work as soon thereafter
as may be. This, by the way, is one reason why it is so hard to find
time for my weekly reports to you. I cannot use my typewriter before goi
to the Library, lest I wake my neighbors, and I am so dead tired on my
return that a letter written then would probably be satisfactory to
neither of us.
With very best remembrances, I remain
div1.closer:
Most truly yours, Laura A. Carter Dr. Frederick F. Russell,
Director,
International Health Division
The Rockefeller Foundation
61 Broadway, New York, N. Y.
